title: Clustering Applications at Yahoo!
segmentation: Thank you for inviting inviting me to give this talk.
I'll be discussing some applications of clustering at Yahoo and this is really not just my work but work from above.
Other people at Yahoo as well.
So.
To get your question clustering in and of itself is rarely the primary goal.
Typically there is some other final goal in mind, and then clustering helps us get to some intermediate point.
Helps us in achieving this final goal in some form or the other, and so typically the methods that we used even for clustering are often tide to this final goal that we have in mind.
So in the rest of the talk, instead of talking about, here is the data.
Here's the clustering method and talk about the data.
What sort of problems we want.
Solve for that data and then how can clustering help us achieve those problem?
Solve those problems.
What are the issues we face?
In particular, I'll try to focus on three basic types of problems, so there are the graph partitioning style of problems where you have, for instance advertisers and the keywords that they bid on.
So this gives you a bipartite graph.
How do we come up with the partitioning of this bipartite graph?
Again, there are many, many social network style datasets at Yahoo.
For instance, who is buddies with whom emails home and so on.
So how do we come up with clusters of people in this setting?
So graph partitioning is one such problem.
Another problem with clustering is useful, but only as an intermediate step is where we want to predict the clickthrough rates of ads and web pages.
So the basic question here is, if I showed this particular ad on this particular page, what is the likelihood of a user clicking on the ad?
Unfortunately, the data here is extremely sparse, and so clustering helps us in actually dealing with this sparsity, but it's not giving us the predictions.

The predictions have to come on top of the clustering method, and that I actually puts in some constraints on what sort of clustering you can do, and typically Co clustering formulations are useful in this setting.
Finally, clustering is useful in the search process itself, in the for the problem of query refinement.
Very suggestions.
I will discuss that, and at the end I'll just conclude.
So.
Graph partitioning there are a bunch of graph like data sets at Yahoo.
Essentially, anytime you have connections between entities, you can think of it as a graph.

The bid on certain keywords.

That was a text that comes in and tells Yahoo.

Would say that based on these particular keywords I believe that you believe belong to this particular cluster of advertisers.

Would you be interested in bidding for digital memory cards?

And for Yahoo.

And Yahoo is happy because.
You're just getting more and more people into your search market, smart search marketplace, driving up prices of driving revenue, and so on.

So here.

This cluster is well separated from the rest so that if you mess up it doesn't go over and mess up the entire sponsored church.

No discussion of graph partitioning is complete without discussing spectral partitioning, so this is 1 old, very widely used method.
There are a bunch of variants of it, but basically it boils down to this.
Take the graph, find its Laplacian, takes the second smallest eigenvalue, also called the eigenvector.
Also the Fiedler vector and this gives you an embedding of all the nodes in the graph in the real line.
Now you pick some spread point.
You say that all nodes through the left are in one cluster, all nodes to the right or in another cluster.
And if you do this right then this can give you an approximation of the optimal conductance.
And conductance is often a metric that people are interested in in measuring the goodness of any partitioning scheme.
So if you want, this gives us two clusters.
If you wanted more clusters, we could use conceivably for K smallest eigenvectors, or what we could do is divide and conquer sort of scheme.
You split the graph in two, you look at each partition.
You split it down into and so on, and you recurse.
This is the basic scheme that had a bunch of variants, but essentially they all have.
This one problem which comes from the data itself.

The problem is that on many of the datasets that Yahoo has, if you try to find the minimum conductance cut that gives you very small chunks, very small clusters, so this is an example on the Yahoo groups data set, so you have users connected to the newsgroups that they read.
And on the X axis we have the size of the smaller partition.
So as you move towards the higher on the X axis you are getting better and better balanced cuts.
Remember we're just getting two partitions on the Y axis.
We have the cushion cut scores, so lower is better and this is a scatter plot of many, many cuts that were found by some algorithm on this graph.
So essentially what we see is that as you go towards better balance, so higher along the X axis you get worse cut scores, so more balanced cuts gives you worse codes.
And if you wanted to get the best possible minimum conductance cut, you would actually go down way down in along the X axis and pick some chunk which is of size 1520 or something like that.
So you do this entire eigenvector computation and all you get out of it is this 20 node partition, which is not really useful.
And if you look at what these partitions are giving you.
The small partitions are really just whiskers off of the main graph.

They're not really well, you know, good components of the large graph, and if you look at the more balanced partitions, these tend to be more like unions of fiscals rather than big good partitions of the graph, which are embedded in the uterus.
So neither of these is really giving us what we had wanted when we wanted to do partitioning.
And So what this means is that if you go for minimum conductance, we're not getting balance.
This has another.
Problem if you wanted to do recursive partitioning then this takes a lot of time.
You do this entire eigenvector computation and then if you have to recurse, you have to do it again on pretty much the entire graph you have broken off only 20 or 30 node chunk out of this graph.
So in order to speed up the computation, there are really.
Two alternatives one.
For more balance, so achieving better balance.
So suppose I wanted to get cuts which had very good balance.
One algorithm to do this is the well known metas algorithm.

This will give us a better or a good balanced cut, but it's a heuristic algorithm, so it's not really going to minimize conductance or minimize the edge cut score or give us any guarantees about that.
So one way is to take matters.
Balanced cuts given by metrics and try to improve those balance cuts.
Perhaps using some flow based improvement technique, so this is actually an algorithm that gets used quite a bit inside Yahoo, and this gives some sort of a trade off.
Fairly good tradeoff between balance and conductance of the cuts.
Another algorithm would be to say that OK, let me enforce stronger balance constraints.

So ideally what we would like is that you have a bunch of nodes which embedded on the real line bunch of loans at minus one bunch of nodes at plus one, But this is hard, so spectral embedding gives us.
A relaxation of this problem, where essentially you just say that OK, the center of mass has to be at the origin.
But this means that one node which is far away from the origin and sort of account for many nodes which are very close to the origin.

Another idea is to do faster computation, but get just unbalanced cards.
So one way to do this is you just pick seeds at random from the graph and then you build clusters around each of these seeds.
Typically this is done using some random walks sort of model, or run a personalized page rank sort of thing and what you do is you run this random walk and then beyond some point you say that OK.
I've found a cluster.
I get this cluster out and then I run the same thing on a different seat on some different portion of the graph.
And the nice thing here is that the time for each iteration is proportional to the size of the cluster that you're picking out of it.

Hopefully, if there is a nice natural cluster around that seed, you bite it off fairly quickly, and this is very useful when you don't need all clusters of the graph, so you don't need an exhaustive clustering.
